title: Negative regulation of ABA signaling by WRKY33 is critical for <italic>Arabidopsis</italic> immunity towards <italic>Botrytis cinerea</italic> 2100
abstract: The <italic>Arabidopsis</italic> mutant <italic>wrky33</italic> is highly susceptible to <italic>Botrytis cinerea</italic>. We identified >1680 <italic>Botrytis</italic>-induced WRKY33 binding sites associated with 1576 <italic>Arabidopsis</italic> genes. Transcriptional profiling defined 318 functional direct target genes at 14 hr post inoculation. Comparative analyses revealed that WRKY33 possesses dual functionality acting either as a repressor or as an activator in a promoter-context dependent manner. We confirmed known WRKY33 targets involved in hormone signaling and phytoalexin biosynthesis, but also uncovered a novel negative role of abscisic acid (ABA) in resistance towards <italic>B. cinerea</italic> 2100. The ABA biosynthesis genes <italic>NCED3</italic> and <italic>NCED5</italic> were identified as direct targets required for WRKY33-mediated resistance. Loss-of-WRKY33 function resulted in elevated ABA levels and genetic studies confirmed that WRKY33 acts upstream of <italic>NCED3/NCED5</italic> to negatively regulate ABA biosynthesis. This study provides the first detailed view of the genome-wide contribution of a specific plant transcription factor in modulating the transcriptional network associated with plant immunity.
